     384                 :            : /**
     385                 :            : * Checks to avoid mempool polluting consensus critical paths since cached
     386                 :            : * signature and script validity results will be reused if we validate this
     387                 :            : * transaction again during block validation.
     388                 :            : * */
     389                 :      66281 : static bool CheckInputsFromMempoolAndCache(const CTransaction& tx, TxValidationState& state,

     611                 :            : 
     612                 :            :     // Run the policy checks on a given transaction, excluding any script checks.
     613                 :            :     // Looks up inputs, calculates feerate, considers replacement, evaluates
     614                 :            :     // package limits, etc. As this function can be invoked for "free" by a peer,
     615                 :            :     // only tests that are fast should be done here (to avoid CPU DoS).
     616                 :            :     bool PreChecks(ATMPArgs& args, Workspace& ws) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main, m_pool.cs);
     617                 :            : 
     618                 :            :     // Run checks for mempool replace-by-fee.
     619                 :            :     bool ReplacementChecks(Workspace& ws) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main, m_pool.cs);
     620                 :            : 
     621                 :            :     // Enforce package mempool ancestor/descendant limits (distinct from individual
     622                 :            :     // ancestor/descendant limits done in PreChecks).

     624                 :            :                               PackageValidationState& package_state) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main, m_pool.cs);
     625                 :            : 
     626                 :            :     // Run the script checks using our policy flags. As this can be slow, we should
     627                 :            :     // only invoke this on transactions that have otherwise passed policy checks.
     628                 :            :     bool PolicyScriptChecks(const ATMPArgs& args, Workspace& ws) EXCLUSIVE_LOCKS_REQUIRED(cs_main, m_pool.cs);
     629                 :            : 
     630                 :            :     // Re-run the script checks, using consensus flags, and try to cache the
     631                 :            :     // result in the scriptcache. This should be done after
     632                 :            :     // PolicyScriptChecks(). This requires that all inputs either be in our
     633                 :            :     // utxo set or in the mempool.

     636                 :            :     // Try to add the transaction to the mempool, removing any conflicts first.
     637                 :            :     // Returns true if the transaction is in the mempool after any size

     640                 :            : 
     641                 :            :     // Submit all transactions to the mempool and call ConsensusScriptChecks to add to the script

     644                 :            :     // transactions are successfully added to the mempool, false otherwise.

     729                 :            :     }
     730                 :            : 
     731                 :            :     // Check for conflicts with in-memory transactions
     732         [ +  + ]:    5884179 :     for (const CTxIn &txin : tx.vin)
     733                 :            :     {
     734         [ +  - ]:    5539859 :         const CTransaction* ptxConflicting = m_pool.GetConflictTx(txin.prevout);
     735         [ +  + ]:    5539859 :         if (ptxConflicting) {
     736         [ +  + ]:     891729 :             if (!args.m_allow_replacement) {
     737                 :            :                 // Transaction conflicts with a mempool tx, but we're not allowing replacements.
     738   [ +  -  +  -  :      90270 :                 return state.Invalid(TxValidationResult::TX_MEMPOOL_POLICY, "bip125-replacement-disallowed");
                   +  - ]
     739                 :            :             }
     740   [ +  -  +  + ]:     801459 :             if (!ws.m_conflicts.count(ptxConflicting->GetHash()))
     741                 :            :             {
     742                 :            :                 // Transactions that don't explicitly signal replaceability are
     743                 :            :                 // *not* replaceable with the current logic, even if one of their
     744                 :            :                 // unconfirmed ancestors signals replaceability. This diverges
     745                 :            :                 // from BIP125's inherited signaling description (see CVE-2021-31876).
     746                 :            :                 // Applications relying on first-seen mempool behavior should
     747                 :            :                 // check all unconfirmed ancestors; otherwise an opt-in ancestor
     748                 :            :                 // might be replaced, causing removal of this descendant.
     749                 :            :                 //
     750                 :            :                 // If replaceability signaling is ignored due to node setting,
     751                 :            :                 // replacement is always allowed.
     752   [ +  -  +  -  :     146445 :                 if (!m_pool.m_full_rbf && !SignalsOptInRBF(*ptxConflicting)) {
                   +  + ]
     753   [ +  -  +  -  :      53833 :                     return state.Invalid(TxValidationResult::TX_MEMPOOL_POLICY, "txn-mempool-conflict");
                   +  - ]
     754                 :            :                 }

     859                 :            : 
     860         [ +  - ]:     159384 :     ws.m_iters_conflicting = m_pool.GetIterSet(ws.m_conflicts);
     861                 :            :     // Calculate in-mempool ancestors, up to a limit.
     862         [ +  + ]:     159384 :     if (ws.m_conflicts.size() == 1) {
     863                 :            :         // In general, when we receive an RBF transaction with mempool conflicts, we want to know whether we
     864                 :            :         // would meet the chain limits after the conflicts have been removed. However, there isn't a practical
     865                 :            :         // way to do this short of calculating the ancestor and descendant sets with an overlay cache of
     866                 :            :         // changed mempool entries. Due to both implementation and runtime complexity concerns, this isn't
     867                 :            :         // very realistic, thus we only ensure a limited set of transactions are RBF'able despite mempool
     868                 :            :         // conflicts here. Importantly, we need to ensure that some transactions which were accepted using
     869                 :            :         // the below carve-out are able to be RBF'ed, without impacting the security the carve-out provides
     870                 :            :         // for off-chain contract systems (see link in the comment below).
     871                 :            :         //
     872                 :            :         // Specifically, the subset of RBF transactions which we allow despite chain limits are those which
     873                 :            :         // conflict directly with exactly one other transaction (but may evict children of said transaction),
     874                 :            :         // and which are not adding any new mempool dependencies. Note that the "no new mempool dependencies"
     875                 :            :         // check is accomplished later, so we don't bother doing anything about it here, but if our
     876                 :            :         // policy changes, we may need to move that check to here instead of removing it wholesale.
     877                 :            :         //
     878                 :            :         // Such transactions are clearly not merging any existing packages, so we are only concerned with
     879                 :            :         // ensuring that (a) no package is growing past the package size (not count) limits and (b) we are
     880                 :            :         // not allowing something to effectively use the (below) carve-out spot when it shouldn't be allowed
     881                 :            :         // to.
     882                 :            :         //
     883                 :            :         // To check these we first check if we meet the RBF criteria, above, and increment the descendant
     884                 :            :         // limits by the direct conflict and its descendants (as these are recalculated in
     885                 :            :         // CalculateMempoolAncestors by assuming the new transaction being added is a new descendant, with no
     886                 :            :         // removals, of each parent's existing dependent set). The ancestor count limits are unmodified (as
     887                 :            :         // the ancestor limits should be the same for both our new transaction and any conflicts).
     888                 :            :         // We don't bother incrementing m_limit_descendants by the full removal count as that limit never comes
     889                 :            :         // into force here (as we're only adding a single transaction).
     890         [ +  - ]:      43925 :         assert(ws.m_iters_conflicting.size() == 1);
     891         [ +  - ]:      43925 :         CTxMemPool::txiter conflict = *ws.m_iters_conflicting.begin();
     892                 :            : 
     893                 :      43925 :         m_limits.descendant_count += 1;
     894   [ +  -  +  - ]:      43925 :         m_limits.descendant_size_vbytes += conflict->GetSizeWithDescendants();
     895                 :      43925 :     }
     896                 :            : 
     897         [ +  - ]:     159384 :     auto ancestors{m_pool.CalculateMemPoolAncestors(*entry, m_limits)};
     898         [ +  + ]:     159384 :     if (!ancestors) {
     899                 :            :         // If CalculateMemPoolAncestors fails second time, we want the original error string.
     900                 :            :         // Contracting/payment channels CPFP carve-out:
     901                 :            :         // If the new transaction is relatively small (up to 40k weight)
     902                 :            :         // and has at most one ancestor (ie ancestor limit of 2, including
     903                 :            :         // the new transaction), allow it if its parent has exactly the
     904                 :            :         // descendant limit descendants.
     905                 :       1806 :         //
     906                 :            :         // This allows protocols which rely on distrusting counterparties
     907                 :       1806 :         // being able to broadcast descendants of an unconfirmed transaction
     908                 :            :         // to be secure by simply only having two immediately-spendable
     909                 :            :         // outputs - one for each counterparty. For more info on the uses for
     910                 :            :         // this, see https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/bitcoin-dev/2018-November/016518.html

     941                 :      36022 : bool MemPoolAccept::ReplacementChecks(Workspace& ws)
     942                 :            : {
     943                 :      36022 :     AssertLockHeld(cs_main);
     944                 :      36022 :     AssertLockHeld(m_pool.cs);
     945                 :            : 
     946                 :      36022 :     const CTransaction& tx = *ws.m_ptx;
     947                 :      36022 :     const uint256& hash = ws.m_hash;
     948                 :      36022 :     TxValidationState& state = ws.m_state;
     949                 :            : 
     950                 :      36022 :     CFeeRate newFeeRate(ws.m_modified_fees, ws.m_vsize);
     951                 :            :     // Enforce Rule #6. The replacement transaction must have a higher feerate than its direct conflicts.
     952                 :            :     // - The motivation for this check is to ensure that the replacement transaction is preferable for
     953                 :            :     //   block-inclusion, compared to what would be removed from the mempool.
     954                 :            :     // - This logic predates ancestor feerate-based transaction selection, which is why it doesn't
     955                 :            :     //   consider feerates of descendants.
     956                 :            :     // - Note: Ancestor feerate-based transaction selection has made this comparison insufficient to
     957                 :            :     //   guarantee that this is incentive-compatible for miners, because it is possible for a
     958                 :            :     //   descendant transaction of a direct conflict to pay a higher feerate than the transaction that
     959                 :            :     //   might replace them, under these rules.
     960   [ +  +  +  + ]:      61628 :     if (const auto err_string{PaysMoreThanConflicts(ws.m_iters_conflicting, newFeeRate, hash)}) {

    1032                 :            : 
    1033                 :      66281 : bool MemPoolAccept::ConsensusScriptChecks(const ATMPArgs& args, Workspace& ws)
    1034                 :            : {
    1035                 :      66281 :     AssertLockHeld(cs_main);
    1036                 :      66281 :     AssertLockHeld(m_pool.cs);
    1037                 :      66281 :     const CTransaction& tx = *ws.m_ptx;
    1038                 :      66281 :     const uint256& hash = ws.m_hash;
    1039                 :      66281 :     TxValidationState& state = ws.m_state;
    1040                 :            : 
    1041                 :            :     // Check again against the current block tip's script verification
    1042                 :            :     // flags to cache our script execution flags. This is, of course,
    1043                 :            :     // useless if the next block has different script flags from the
    1044                 :            :     // previous one, but because the cache tracks script flags for us it
    1045                 :            :     // will auto-invalidate and we'll just have a few blocks of extra
    1046                 :            :     // misses on soft-fork activation.
    1047                 :            :     //
    1048                 :            :     // This is also useful in case of bugs in the standard flags that cause
    1049                 :            :     // transactions to pass as valid when they're actually invalid. For
    1050                 :            :     // instance the STRICTENC flag was incorrectly allowing certain
    1051                 :            :     // CHECKSIG NOT scripts to pass, even though they were invalid.
    1052                 :            :     //
    1053                 :            :     // There is a similar check in CreateNewBlock() to prevent creating
    1054                 :            :     // invalid blocks (using TestBlockValidity), however allowing such

    1329                 :            : 
    1330                 :        143 : PackageMempoolAcceptResult MemPoolAccept::AcceptPackage(const Package& package, ATMPArgs& args)
    1331                 :            : {
    1332                 :        143 :     AssertLockHeld(cs_main);
    1333                 :            :     // Used if returning a PackageMempoolAcceptResult directly from this function.
    1334                 :        143 :     PackageValidationState package_state_quit_early;
    1335                 :            : 
    1336                 :            :     // Check that the package is well-formed. If it isn't, we won't try to validate any of the
    1337                 :            :     // transactions and thus won't return any MempoolAcceptResults, just a package-wide error.
    1338                 :            : 
    1339                 :            :     // Context-free package checks.
    1340   [ +  -  +  +  :        143 :     if (!CheckPackage(package, package_state_quit_early)) return PackageMempoolAcceptResult(package_state_quit_early, {});
             +  -  +  - ]
    1341                 :            : 
    1342                 :            :     // All transactions in the package must be a parent of the last transaction. This is just an
    1343                 :            :     // opportunity for us to fail fast on a context-free check without taking the mempool lock.
    1344   [ +  -  +  + ]:        140 :     if (!IsChildWithParents(package)) {

    1346   [ +  -  +  - ]:        129 :         return PackageMempoolAcceptResult(package_state_quit_early, {});

    1361                 :            :     // mempool), and enforce that all parents not present in the package be available at chain tip.
    1362                 :            :     // Since this check can bring new coins into the coins cache, keep track of these coins and

    1383         [ #  # ]:          0 :     m_view.SetBackend(m_dummy);
    1384                 :            : 
    1385   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :     LOCK(m_pool.cs);
    1386                 :            :     // Stores final results that won't change
    1387                 :          0 :     std::map<const uint256, const MempoolAcceptResult> results_final;
    1388                 :            :     // Node operators are free to set their mempool policies however they please, nodes may receive
    1389                 :            :     // transactions in different orders, and malicious counterparties may try to take advantage of
    1390                 :            :     // policy differences to pin or delay propagation of transactions. As such, it's possible for
    1391                 :            :     // some package transaction(s) to already be in the mempool, and we don't want to reject the
    1392                 :            :     // entire package in that case (as that could be a censorship vector). De-duplicate the
    1393                 :            :     // transactions that are already in the mempool, and only call AcceptMultipleTransactions() with
    1394                 :            :     // the new transactions. This ensures we don't double-count transaction counts and sizes when
    1395                 :            :     // checking ancestor/descendant limits, or double-count transaction fees for fee-related policy.
    1396         [ #  # ]:          0 :     ATMPArgs single_args = ATMPArgs::SingleInPackageAccept(args);
    1397                 :            :     // Results from individual validation. "Nonfinal" because if a transaction fails by itself but
    1398                 :            :     // succeeds later (i.e. when evaluated with a fee-bumping child), the result changes (though not
    1399                 :            :     // reflected in this map). If a transaction fails more than once, we want to return the first
    1400                 :            :     // result, when it was considered on its own. So changes will only be from invalid -> valid.
    1401                 :          0 :     std::map<uint256, MempoolAcceptResult> individual_results_nonfinal;
    1402                 :          0 :     bool quit_early{false};
    1403                 :          0 :     std::vector<CTransactionRef> txns_package_eval;

    1405         [ #  # ]:          0 :         const auto& wtxid = tx->GetWitnessHash();
    1406                 :          0 :         const auto& txid = tx->GetHash();
    1407                 :            :         // There are 3 possibilities: already in mempool, same-txid-diff-wtxid already in mempool,
    1408                 :            :         // or not in mempool. An already confirmed tx is treated as one not in mempool, because all
    1409                 :            :         // we know is that the inputs aren't available.
    1410   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :         if (m_pool.exists(GenTxid::Wtxid(wtxid))) {

    1438                 :            :                 // Package validation policy only differs from individual policy in its evaluation
    1439                 :            :                 // of feerate. For example, if a transaction fails here due to violation of a

    1758                 :            : 
    1759                 :            : /**
    1760                 :            :  * Check whether all of this transaction's input scripts succeed.
    1761                 :            :  *
    1762                 :            :  * This involves ECDSA signature checks so can be computationally intensive. This function should
    1763                 :            :  * only be called after the cheap sanity checks in CheckTxInputs passed.
    1764                 :            :  *
    1765                 :            :  * If pvChecks is not nullptr, script checks are pushed onto it instead of being performed inline. Any
    1766                 :            :  * script checks which are not necessary (eg due to script execution cache hits) are, obviously,
    1767                 :            :  * not pushed onto pvChecks/run.
    1768                 :            :  *
    1769                 :            :  * Setting cacheSigStore/cacheFullScriptStore to false will remove elements from the corresponding cache
    1770                 :            :  * which are matched. This is useful for checking blocks where we will likely never need the cache
    1771                 :            :  * entry again.
    1772                 :            :  *
    1773                 :            :  * Note that we may set state.reason to NOT_STANDARD for extra soft-fork flags in flags, block-checking
    1774                 :            :  * callers should probably reset it to CONSENSUS in such cases.
    1775                 :            :  *
    1776                 :            :  * Non-static (and re-declared) in src/test/txvalidationcache_tests.cpp
    1777                 :            :  */

    1887                 :            :         // outputs. This implies that it must be present for some other output of the same tx.
    1888                 :          0 :         const Coin& alternate = AccessByTxid(view, out.hash);

    1895                 :          0 :     }

    1916                 :          0 :         return DISCONNECT_FAILED;
    1917                 :            :     }
    1918                 :            :

    1921                 :          0 :         return DISCONNECT_FAILED;
    1922                 :            :     }
    1923                 :            : 
    1924                 :            :     // Ignore blocks that contain transactions which are 'overwritten' by later transactions,
    1925                 :            :     // unless those are already completely spent.
    1926                 :            :     // See https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/22596 for additional information.
    1927                 :            :     // Note: the blocks specified here are different than the ones used in ConnectBlock because DisconnectBlock
    1928                 :            :     // unwinds the blocks in reverse. As a result, the inconsistency is not discovered until the earlier
    1929                 :            :     // blocks with the duplicate coinbase transactions are disconnected.
    1930   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :     bool fEnforceBIP30 = !((pindex->nHeight==91722 && pindex->GetBlockHash() == uint256S("0x00000000000271a2dc26e7667f8419f2e15416dc6955e5a6c6cdf3f2574dd08e")) ||

    1932                 :            :

    1991                 :            : /**
    1992                 :            :  * Threshold condition checker that triggers when unknown versionbits are seen on the network.

    1994                 :            : class WarningBitsConditionChecker : public AbstractThresholdConditionChecker
    1995                 :            : {
    1996                 :            : private:
    1997                 :            :     const ChainstateManager& m_chainman;
    1998                 :            :     int m_bit;
    1999                 :            : 
    2000                 :            : public:
    2001                 :          0 :     explicit WarningBitsConditionChecker(const ChainstateManager& chainman, int bit) : m_chainman{chainman}, m_bit(bit) {}
    2002                 :            : 
    2003                 :          0 :     int64_t BeginTime(const Consensus::Params& params) const override { return 0; }
    2004                 :          0 :     int64_t EndTime(const Consensus::Params& params) const override { return std::numeric_limits<int64_t>::max(); }
    2005                 :          0 :     int Period(const Consensus::Params& params) const override { return params.nMinerConfirmationWindow; }
    2006                 :          0 :     int Threshold(const Consensus::Params& params) const override { return params.nRuleChangeActivationThreshold; }
    2007                 :            : 
    2008                 :          0 :     bool Condition(const CBlockIndex* pindex, const Consensus::Params& params) const override
    2009                 :            :     {
    2010         [ #  # ]:          0 :         return pindex->nHeight >= params.MinBIP9WarningHeight &&
    2011         [ #  # ]:          0 :                ((pindex->nVersion & VERSIONBITS_TOP_MASK) == VERSIONBITS_TOP_BITS) &&

    2019                 :      94207 : static unsigned int GetBlockScriptFlags(const CBlockIndex& block_index, const ChainstateManager& chainman)
    2020                 :            : {
    2021                 :      94207 :     const Consensus::Params& consensusparams = chainman.GetConsensus();
    2022                 :            : 
    2023                 :            :     // BIP16 didn't become active until Apr 1 2012 (on mainnet, and
    2024                 :            :     // retroactively applied to testnet)
    2025                 :            :     // However, only one historical block violated the P2SH rules (on both
    2026                 :            :     // mainnet and testnet).
    2027                 :            :     // Similarly, only one historical block violated the TAPROOT rules on
    2028                 :            :     // mainnet.

    2069                 :            : 
    2070                 :            : /** Apply the effects of this block (with given index) on the UTXO set represented by coins.
    2071                 :            :  *  Validity checks that depend on the UTXO set are also done; ConnectBlock()
    2072                 :            :  *  can fail if those validity checks fail (among other reasons). */
    2073                 :      29732 : bool Chainstate::ConnectBlock(const CBlock& block, BlockValidationState& state, CBlockIndex* pindex,
    2074                 :            :                                CCoinsViewCache& view, bool fJustCheck)
    2075                 :            : {
    2076                 :      29732 :     AssertLockHeld(cs_main);
    2077         [ +  - ]:      29732 :     assert(pindex);
    2078                 :            : 
    2079                 :      29732 :     uint256 block_hash{block.GetHash()};
    2080         [ +  - ]:      29732 :     assert(*pindex->phashBlock == block_hash);
    2081                 :      29732 :     const bool parallel_script_checks{scriptcheckqueue.HasThreads()};
    2082                 :            : 
    2083                 :      29732 :     const auto time_start{SteadyClock::now()};
    2084                 :      29732 :     const CChainParams& params{m_chainman.GetParams()};
    2085                 :            : 
    2086                 :            :     // Check it again in case a previous version let a bad block in
    2087                 :            :     // NOTE: We don't currently (re-)invoke ContextualCheckBlock() or
    2088                 :            :     // ContextualCheckBlockHeader() here. This means that if we add a new
    2089                 :            :     // consensus rule that is enforced in one of those two functions, then we
    2090                 :            :     // may have let in a block that violates the rule prior to updating the
    2091                 :            :     // software, and we would NOT be enforcing the rule here. Fully solving
    2092                 :            :     // upgrade from one software version to the next after a consensus rule
    2093                 :            :     // change is potentially tricky and issue-specific (see NeedsRedownload()
    2094                 :            :     // for one approach that was used for BIP 141 deployment).
    2095                 :            :     // Also, currently the rule against blocks more than 2 hours in the future
    2096                 :            :     // is enforced in ContextualCheckBlockHeader(); we wouldn't want to
    2097                 :            :     // re-enforce that rule here (at least until we make it impossible for
    2098                 :            :     // m_adjusted_time_callback() to go backward).
    2099         [ +  - ]:      29732 :     if (!CheckBlock(block, state, params.GetConsensus(), !fJustCheck, !fJustCheck)) {
    2100         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (state.GetResult() == BlockValidationResult::BLOCK_MUTATED) {
    2101                 :            :             // We don't write down blocks to disk if they may have been
    2102                 :            :             // corrupted, so this should be impossible unless we're having hardware
    2103                 :            :             // problems.
    2104   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             return AbortNode(state, "Corrupt block found indicating potential hardware failure; shutting down");

    2123                 :      27926 :     bool fScriptChecks = true;
    2124         [ +  - ]:      27926 :     if (!m_chainman.AssumedValidBlock().IsNull()) {
    2125                 :            :         // We've been configured with the hash of a block which has been externally verified to have a valid history.
    2126                 :            :         // A suitable default value is included with the software and updated from time to time.  Because validity
    2127                 :            :         //  relative to a piece of software is an objective fact these defaults can be easily reviewed.
    2128                 :            :         // This setting doesn't force the selection of any particular chain but makes validating some faster by
    2129                 :            :         //  effectively caching the result of part of the verification.
    2130                 :          0 :         BlockMap::const_iterator it{m_blockman.m_block_index.find(m_chainman.AssumedValidBlock())};

    2132   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             if (it->second.GetAncestor(pindex->nHeight) == pindex &&
    2133         [ #  # ]:          0 :                 m_chainman.m_best_header->GetAncestor(pindex->nHeight) == pindex &&
    2134                 :          0 :                 m_chainman.m_best_header->nChainWork >= m_chainman.MinimumChainWork()) {
    2135                 :            :                 // This block is a member of the assumed verified chain and an ancestor of the best header.
    2136                 :            :                 // Script verification is skipped when connecting blocks under the
    2137                 :            :                 // assumevalid block. Assuming the assumevalid block is valid this
    2138                 :            :                 // is safe because block merkle hashes are still computed and checked,
    2139                 :            :                 // Of course, if an assumed valid block is invalid due to false scriptSigs
    2140                 :            :                 // this optimization would allow an invalid chain to be accepted.
    2141                 :            :                 // The equivalent time check discourages hash power from extorting the network via DOS attack
    2142                 :            :                 //  into accepting an invalid block through telling users they must manually set assumevalid.
    2143                 :            :                 //  Requiring a software change or burying the invalid block, regardless of the setting, makes
    2144                 :            :                 //  it hard to hide the implication of the demand.  This also avoids having release candidates
    2145                 :            :                 //  that are hardly doing any signature verification at all in testing without having to
    2146                 :            :                 //  artificially set the default assumed verified block further back.
    2147                 :            :                 // The test against the minimum chain work prevents the skipping when denied access to any chain at
    2148                 :            :                 //  least as good as the expected chain.
    2149                 :          0 :                 fScriptChecks = (GetBlockProofEquivalentTime(*m_chainman.m_best_header, *pindex, *m_chainman.m_best_header, params.GetConsensus()) <= 60 * 60 * 24 * 7 * 2);

    2153                 :            : 
    2154                 :      27926 :     const auto time_1{SteadyClock::now()};

    2156   [ +  +  +  -  :      27926 :     LogPrint(BCLog::BENCH, "    - Sanity checks: %.2fms [%.2fs (%.2fms/blk)]\n",

          -  +  -  +  -  
                   +  - ]
    2157                 :            :              Ticks<MillisecondsDouble>(time_1 - time_start),
    2158                 :            :              Ticks<SecondsDouble>(time_check),
    2159                 :            :              Ticks<MillisecondsDouble>(time_check) / num_blocks_total);
    2160                 :            : 
    2161                 :            :     // Do not allow blocks that contain transactions which 'overwrite' older transactions,
    2162                 :            :     // unless those are already completely spent.
    2163                 :            :     // If such overwrites are allowed, coinbases and transactions depending upon those
    2164                 :            :     // can be duplicated to remove the ability to spend the first instance -- even after
    2165                 :            :     // being sent to another address.
    2166                 :            :     // See BIP30, CVE-2012-1909, and http://r6.ca/blog/20120206T005236Z.html for more information.
    2167                 :            :     // This rule was originally applied to all blocks with a timestamp after March 15, 2012, 0:00 UTC.
    2168                 :            :     // Now that the whole chain is irreversibly beyond that time it is applied to all blocks except the
    2169                 :            :     // two in the chain that violate it. This prevents exploiting the issue against nodes during their
    2170                 :            :     // initial block download.
    2171                 :      27926 :     bool fEnforceBIP30 = !IsBIP30Repeat(*pindex);
    2172                 :            : 
    2173                 :            :     // Once BIP34 activated it was not possible to create new duplicate coinbases and thus other than starting
    2174                 :            :     // with the 2 existing duplicate coinbase pairs, not possible to create overwriting txs.  But by the
    2175                 :            :     // time BIP34 activated, in each of the existing pairs the duplicate coinbase had overwritten the first
    2176                 :            :     // before the first had been spent.  Since those coinbases are sufficiently buried it's no longer possible to create further
    2177                 :            :     // duplicate transactions descending from the known pairs either.
    2178                 :            :     // If we're on the known chain at height greater than where BIP34 activated, we can save the db accesses needed for the BIP30 check.
    2179                 :            : 
    2180                 :            :     // BIP34 requires that a block at height X (block X) has its coinbase
    2181                 :            :     // scriptSig start with a CScriptNum of X (indicated height X).  The above
    2182                 :            :     // logic of no longer requiring BIP30 once BIP34 activates is flawed in the
    2183                 :            :     // case that there is a block X before the BIP34 height of 227,931 which has
    2184                 :            :     // an indicated height Y where Y is greater than X.  The coinbase for block
    2185                 :            :     // X would also be a valid coinbase for block Y, which could be a BIP30
    2186                 :            :     // violation.  An exhaustive search of all mainnet coinbases before the
    2187                 :            :     // BIP34 height which have an indicated height greater than the block height
    2188                 :            :     // reveals many occurrences. The 3 lowest indicated heights found are
    2189                 :            :     // 209,921, 490,897, and 1,983,702 and thus coinbases for blocks at these 3
    2190                 :            :     // heights would be the first opportunity for BIP30 to be violated.
    2191                 :            : 
    2192                 :            :     // The search reveals a great many blocks which have an indicated height
    2193                 :            :     // greater than 1,983,702, so we simply remove the optimization to skip
    2194                 :            :     // BIP30 checking for blocks at height 1,983,702 or higher.  Before we reach
    2195                 :            :     // that block in another 25 years or so, we should take advantage of a
    2196                 :            :     // future consensus change to do a new and improved version of BIP34 that
    2197                 :            :     // will actually prevent ever creating any duplicate coinbases in the
    2198                 :            :     // future.
    2199                 :            :     static constexpr int BIP34_IMPLIES_BIP30_LIMIT = 1983702;
    2200                 :            : 
    2201                 :            :     // There is no potential to create a duplicate coinbase at block 209,921
    2202                 :            :     // because this is still before the BIP34 height and so explicit BIP30
    2203                 :            :     // checking is still active.
    2204                 :            : 
    2205                 :            :     // The final case is block 176,684 which has an indicated height of
    2206                 :            :     // 490,897. Unfortunately, this issue was not discovered until about 2 weeks
    2207                 :            :     // before block 490,897 so there was not much opportunity to address this
    2208                 :            :     // case other than to carefully analyze it and determine it would not be a
    2209                 :            :     // problem. Block 490,897 was, in fact, mined with a different coinbase than
    2210                 :            :     // block 176,684, but it is important to note that even if it hadn't been or
    2211                 :            :     // is remined on an alternate fork with a duplicate coinbase, we would still
    2212                 :            :     // not run into a BIP30 violation.  This is because the coinbase for 176,684
    2213                 :            :     // is spent in block 185,956 in transaction
    2214                 :            :     // d4f7fbbf92f4a3014a230b2dc70b8058d02eb36ac06b4a0736d9d60eaa9e8781.  This
    2215                 :            :     // spending transaction can't be duplicated because it also spends coinbase
    2216                 :            :     // 0328dd85c331237f18e781d692c92de57649529bd5edf1d01036daea32ffde29.  This
    2217                 :            :     // coinbase has an indicated height of over 4.2 billion, and wouldn't be
    2218                 :            :     // duplicatable until that height, and it's currently impossible to create a
    2219                 :            :     // chain that long. Nevertheless we may wish to consider a future soft fork
    2220                 :            :     // which retroactively prevents block 490,897 from creating a duplicate
    2221                 :            :     // coinbase. The two historical BIP30 violations often provide a confusing
    2222                 :            :     // edge case when manipulating the UTXO and it would be simpler not to have
    2223                 :            :     // another edge case to deal with.
    2224                 :            : 
    2225                 :            :     // testnet3 has no blocks before the BIP34 height with indicated heights
    2226                 :            :     // post BIP34 before approximately height 486,000,000. After block
    2227                 :            :     // 1,983,702 testnet3 starts doing unnecessary BIP30 checking again.
    2228         [ +  - ]:      27926 :     assert(pindex->pprev);
    2229                 :      27926 :     CBlockIndex* pindexBIP34height = pindex->pprev->GetAncestor(params.GetConsensus().BIP34Height);

    2688                 :            : /** Disconnect m_chain's tip.

    2690                 :            :   * transactions from disconnected blocks being added to disconnectpool.  You

    2797                 :       9608 :     std::vector<PerBlockConnectTrace>& GetBlocksConnected() {
    2798                 :            :         // We always keep one extra block at the end of our list because
    2799                 :            :         // blocks are added after all the conflicted transactions have
    2800                 :            :         // been filled in. Thus, the last entry should always be an empty
    2801                 :            :         // one waiting for the transactions from the next block. We pop
    2802                 :            :         // the last entry here to make sure the list we return is sane.
    2803         [ +  - ]:       9608 :         assert(!blocksConnected.back().pindex);
    2804                 :       9608 :         blocksConnected.pop_back();

    2915                 :      71684 : CBlockIndex* Chainstate::FindMostWorkChain()
    2916                 :            : {
    2917                 :      71684 :     AssertLockHeld(::cs_main);
    2918                 :      71684 :     do {
    2919                 :      71684 :         CBlockIndex *pindexNew = nullptr;
    2920                 :            :

    2925                 :          0 :                 return nullptr;
    2926                 :      71684 :             pindexNew = *it;
    2927                 :            :         }
    2928                 :            : 
    2929                 :            :         // Check whether all blocks on the path between the currently active chain and the candidate are valid.
    2930                 :            :         // Just going until the active chain is an optimization, as we know all blocks in it are valid already.
    2931                 :      71684 :         CBlockIndex *pindexTest = pindexNew;
    2932                 :      71684 :         bool fInvalidAncestor = false;
    2933   [ +  +  +  + ]:      81292 :         while (pindexTest && !m_chain.Contains(pindexTest)) {

    2937                 :            :             // which block files have been deleted.  Remove those as candidates
    2938                 :            :             // for the most work chain if we come across them; we can't switch
    2939                 :            :             // to a chain unless we have all the non-active-chain parent blocks.
    2940                 :       9608 :             bool fFailedChain = pindexTest->nStatus & BLOCK_FAILED_MASK;
    2941                 :       9608 :             bool fMissingData = !(pindexTest->nStatus & BLOCK_HAVE_DATA);

    3281                 :            :     // We do not allow ActivateBestChain() to run while InvalidateBlock() is
    3282                 :            :     // running, as that could cause the tip to change while we disconnect
    3283                 :            :     // blocks.
    3284                 :          0 :     LOCK(m_chainstate_mutex);
    3285                 :            : 
    3286                 :            :     // We'll be acquiring and releasing cs_main below, to allow the validation
    3287                 :            :     // callbacks to run. However, we should keep the block index in a
    3288                 :            :     // consistent state as we disconnect blocks -- in particular we need to
    3289                 :            :     // add equal-work blocks to setBlockIndexCandidates as we disconnect.
    3290                 :            :     // To avoid walking the block index repeatedly in search of candidates,
    3291                 :            :     // build a map once so that we can look up candidate blocks by chain
    3292                 :            :     // work as we go.
    3293                 :          0 :     std::multimap<const arith_uint256, CBlockIndex *> candidate_blocks_by_work;

    3296   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :         LOCK(cs_main);

    3298                 :          0 :             CBlockIndex* candidate = &entry.second;
    3299                 :            :             // We don't need to put anything in our active chain into the
    3300                 :            :             // multimap, because those candidates will be found and considered
    3301                 :            :             // as we disconnect.
    3302                 :            :             // Instead, consider only non-active-chain blocks that have at
    3303                 :            :             // least as much work as where we expect the new tip to end up.

    3616                 :      49032 : arith_uint256 CalculateHeadersWork(const std::vector<CBlockHeader>& headers)
    3617                 :            : {
    3618                 :      49032 :     arith_uint256 total_work{0};

    3624                 :            : }
    3625                 :            : 
    3626                 :            : /** Context-dependent validity checks.
    3627                 :            :  *  By "context", we mean only the previous block headers, but not the UTXO
    3628                 :            :  *  set; UTXO-related validity checks are done in ConnectBlock().
    3629                 :            :  *  NOTE: This function is not currently invoked by ConnectBlock(), so we
    3630                 :            :  *  should consider upgrade issues if we change which consensus rules are

    3714      [ -  -  + ]:      27920 :     }
    3715                 :            : 
    3716                 :            :     // Validation for witness commitments.
    3717                 :            :     // * We compute the witness hash (which is the hash including witnesses) of all the block's transactions, except the
    3718                 :            :     //   coinbase (where 0x0000....0000 is used instead).
    3719                 :            :     // * The coinbase scriptWitness is a stack of a single 32-byte vector, containing a witness reserved value (unconstrained).
    3720                 :            :     // * We build a merkle tree with all those witness hashes as leaves (similar to the hashMerkleRoot in the block header).
    3721                 :            :     // * There must be at least one output whose scriptPubKey is a single 36-byte push, the first 4 bytes of which are
    3722                 :            :     //   {0xaa, 0x21, 0xa9, 0xed}, and the following 32 bytes are SHA256^2(witness root, witness reserved value). In case there are
    3723                 :            :     //   multiple, the last one is used.
    3724                 :      27926 :     bool fHaveWitness = false;
    3725         [ -  + ]:      27926 :     if (DeploymentActiveAfter(pindexPrev, chainman, Consensus::DEPLOYMENT_SEGWIT)) {

    3728                 :      27926 :             bool malleated = false;
    3729                 :      27926 :             uint256 hashWitness = BlockWitnessMerkleRoot(block, &malleated);
    3730                 :            :             // The malleation check is ignored; as the transaction tree itself
    3731                 :            :             // already does not permit it, it is impossible to trigger in the
    3732                 :            :             // witness tree.

                   #  # ]
    3735                 :            :             }

    3810                 :            :          * them as failed. For example:
    3811                 :            :          *
    3812                 :            :          *                D3
    3813                 :            :          *              /
    3814                 :            :          *      B2 - C2
    3815                 :            :          *    /         \
    3816                 :            :          *  A             D2 - E2 - F2
    3817                 :            :          *    \
    3818                 :            :          *      B1 - C1 - D1 - E1
    3819                 :            :          *
    3820                 :            :          * In the case that we attempted to reorg from E1 to F2, only to find
    3821                 :            :          * C2 to be invalid, we would mark D2, E2, and F2 as BLOCK_FAILED_CHILD
    3822                 :            :          * but NOT D3 (it was not in any of our candidate sets at the time).
    3823                 :            :          *
    3824                 :            :          * In any case D3 will also be marked as BLOCK_FAILED_CHILD at restart
    3825                 :            :          * in LoadBlockIndex.
    3826                 :            :          */

    4454                 :            : 
    4455                 :            :                 // Fill each chainstate's block candidate set. Only add assumed-valid
    4456                 :            :                 // blocks to the tip candidate set if the chainstate is allowed to rely on
    4457                 :            :                 // assumed-valid blocks.
    4458                 :            :                 //
    4459                 :            :                 // If all setBlockIndexCandidates contained the assumed-valid blocks, the
    4460                 :            :                 // background chainstate's ActivateBestChain() call would add assumed-valid
    4461                 :            :                 // blocks to the chain (based on how FindMostWorkChain() works). Obviously
    4462                 :            :                 // we don't want this since the purpose of the background validation chain
    4463                 :            :                 // is to validate assued-valid blocks.
    4464                 :            :                 //
    4465                 :            :                 // Note: This is considering all blocks whose height is greater or equal to
    4466                 :            :                 // the first assumed-valid block to be assumed-valid blocks, and excluding
    4467                 :            :                 // them from the background chainstate's setBlockIndexCandidates set. This
    4468                 :            :                 // does mean that some blocks which are not technically assumed-valid
    4469                 :            :                 // (later blocks on a fork beginning before the first assumed-valid block)
    4470                 :            :                 // might not get added to the background chainstate, but this is ok,
    4471                 :            :                 // because they will still be attached to the active chainstate if they
    4472                 :            :                 // actually contain more work.
    4473                 :            :                 //
    4474                 :            :                 // Instead of this height-based approach, an earlier attempt was made at
    4475                 :            :                 // detecting "holistically" whether the block index under consideration
    4476                 :            :                 // relied on an assumed-valid ancestor, but this proved to be too slow to
    4477                 :            :                 // be practical.

    4681   [ +  -  +  -  :     268676 :             } catch (const std::exception& e) {
                      + ]
    4682                 :            :                 // historical bugs added extra data to the block files that does not deserialize cleanly.
    4683                 :            :                 // commonly this data is between readable blocks, but it does not really matter. such data is not fatal to the import process.
    4684                 :            :                 // the code that reads the block files deals with invalid data by simply ignoring it.
    4685                 :            :                 // it continues to search for the next {4 byte magic message start bytes + 4 byte length + block} that does deserialize cleanly
    4686                 :            :                 // and passes all of the other block validation checks dealing with POW and the merkle root, etc...
    4687                 :            :                 // we merely note with this informational log message when unexpected data is encountered.
    4688                 :            :                 // we could also be experiencing a storage system read error, or a read of a previous bad write. these are possible, but
    4689                 :            :                 // less likely scenarios. we don't have enough information to tell a difference here.
    4690                 :            :                 // the reindex process is not the place to attempt to clean and/or compact the block files. if so desired, a studious node operator
    4691                 :            :                 // may use knowledge of the fact that the block files are not entirely pristine in order to prepare a set of pristine, and
    4692                 :            :                 // perhaps ordered, block files for later reindexing.
    4693   [ +  -  +  -  :      18349 :                 LogPrint(BCLog::REINDEX, "%s: unexpected data at file offset 0x%x - %s. continuing\n", __func__, (nRewind - 1), e.what());

                      # ]
    4694   [ +  -  #  # ]:      18349 :             }

    5083                 :            :     // Cache percentages to allocate to each chainstate.
    5084                 :            :     //
    5085                 :            :     // These particular percentages don't matter so much since they will only be
    5086                 :            :     // relevant during snapshot activation; caches are rebalanced at the conclusion of
    5087                 :            :     // this function. We want to give (essentially) all available cache capacity to the
    5088                 :            :     // snapshot to aid the bulk load later in this function.

    5097                 :            :         // (optimistically) getting to its tip will be the top priority. We'll need to call

    5400                 :            : // Currently, this function holds cs_main for its duration, which could be for
    5401                 :            : // multiple minutes due to the ComputeUTXOStats call. This hold is necessary

    5403                 :            : // farther than the snapshot base block - and this function is also invoked
    5404                 :            : // from within ConnectTip, i.e. from within ActivateBestChain, so cs_main is
